_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Addition of two compressors and one evap condensor

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Valley Queen Cheese plant, located in Milbank, South Dakota is a producer of various types of cheeses produced from milk.  This plant has a closed loop refrigeration system containing ammonia for maintaining cooler temperatures for the handling and storage of the cheese.

Ammonia is used at the plant to refrigerate rooms to maintain a correct temperature as required by the cheese process.  Ammonia is a valuable chemical used in the plant refrigeration system, providing the means to maintain specified temperature and / or remove heat from the products being handled.  Ammonia is contained in equipment in the plant and is compressed, condensed and evaporated to remove heat from rooms within the facility.

Since ammonia is classified by EPA as a toxic chemical, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling the chemical to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the health threat to our own workers, and reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this plant.  

The plant has completed an expansion of the existing ammonia refrigeration process.  The entire refrigeration system is new. This new system will result in the process containing 19,000 pounds of ammonia and therefore an OSHA Process Safety Management and EPA Risk Management Plan has been implemented.  It is the intent of this cheese plant to comply with OSHA¿s Process Safety Management and EPA¿s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. 

The plant ammonia refrigeration operators are trained using various methods such as on the job training, contractor explanation and training (contractors are members of IIAR).  This program consists of having an effective preventative maintenance program and employee training to insure adequate response to equipment integrity.    Employees are initially trained and have

refresher training in the operation of the ammonia refrigeration system at least every three years.  

The ammonia refrigeration system is computer operated with on-site and remote access for control of the system.  If an alarm should occur, and auto paging text system contacts the operator.  An ammonia detection system is in place which alarms if ammonia is sensed.  The ammonia refrigeration system is also protected by specific safety systems/hardware and safety cutouts including pressure, temperature and level control.  Safety relief valves protect the compressor discharge, condensers, and vessels from the hazards associated with overpressure.  

The process has numerous safe guards including:  
¿	Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.    
¿	Most of the lines are elevated to minimize potential damage from fork lifts.  
¿	The plant has an overall safety program that includes employee awareness and training to minimize the potential for an accident or incident involving the ammonia refrigeration equipment.  
¿	A process hazard analysis (PHA) was conducted in 2007.  A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHA addressed:  (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety and health effects of control system failures.  
¿	Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The SOPs include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  
¿	For plant projects, a management of change procedure and a pre-startup safety review are in place to ensure

that system changes or expansions are safe and that the changes are consistent with the engineering design and in condition to be operated prior to startup.  
¿	Contractors that are used to work on, or adjacent to, the refrigeration system are "pre-qualified" based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.  Each of these contractors is evaluated from a safety perspective.  
¿	The plant has a program for replacement of all pressure relief valves every five years.
 
The plant has an emergency response program based upon federal guidelines as they apply to this facility.  The emergency response plan includes in-house response capabilities in the event of a release, procedures for notification of the local fire authority, local emergency response agencies, and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. The plant emergency action plan is based on all known applicable regulations and requirements and responders are trained as required.  

The plant has had no reportable release in the past five year history.

This new system was operational on 8/21/2007. The first 3 year compliance audit will be completed prior to 8/21/2010.
